If McConnell wins, Ted Cruz may not back him

First headache for Sen. Mitch McConnell if he wins: arm-wrestling with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz over party leadership

If McConnell wins, Ted Cruz may not back him

Politics

James R. Carroll, The Courier-Journal 4:01 p.m. EST November 4, 2014

Sen. Mitch McConnell and wife Elaine Chao vote at Bellarmine University on Tuesday morning. (By Alton Strupp/The CJ)

Buy Photo

Senator Mitch McConnell arrives with wife Elaine Chao at Bellarmine University to vote. November 4, 2014(Photo: Michael Clevenger/The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

Tags

  • Ted Cruz
  • Mitch McConnell
  • Republican Party
8 CONNECT 99 TWEETLINKEDIN 2 COMMENTEMAILMORE

LOUISVILLE - If Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell wins re-election Tuesday, his prize may be a restive Republican caucus with a rebellious would-be presidential candidate who may not support him.

Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who has worked with other tea-party Republicans to force government crises over spending, budgets and the debt ceiling, said over the weekend in a Washington Post interview he is aiming for a GOP-led Senate that is just as confrontational with the White House as the Republican House has been.

Cruz said the Senate under Republicans should begin their work "looking at the abuse of power, the executive abuse, the regulatory abuse, the lawlessness that sadly has pervaded this administration."

Cruz also told The Post he wanted a Republican Senate to vigorously pursue repeal of the Affordable Care Act.

Significantly, Cruz also would not pledge his support to McConnell as majority leader.

RELATED: Turnout "steady" across Kentucky

RELATED: FiveThirtyEight gives McConnell 98% chance of winning

Consequently, McConnell could return to the nation's capital trying to tamp down internal party divisions that not only would make his life more difficult but also create an even less favorable atmosphere for the GOP's uphill fight to maintain control of the Senate in 2016.

Many more Republican Senate seats than Democratic ones will be up then, and many of those GOP seats are in states President Barack Obama won in 2008 and 2012.

That less friendly terrain for Republicans would mean a less confrontational legislative agenda, with potential for accomplishments and compromises, would be more helpful to them than what Cruz envisions.

Cruz is considered a possible 2016 presidential contender.
